natural problem: How many different isosceles triangles have integer side lengths and perimeter 23?
natural solution: Because the perimeter of such a triangle is 23, and the sum of the two equal side lengths is even, the length of the base is odd. Also, the length of the base is less than the sum of the other two side lengths, so it is less than half of 23.
Thus the $\boxed{6}$ possible triangles have side lengths 1, 11, 11; 3, 10, 10; 5, 9, 9; 7, 8, 8; 9, 7, 7 and 11, 6, 6.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a + b + c = 23"
and h1 : "a = b \<or> b = c \<or> a = c"
shows  "card {(a, b, c). a + b + c = 23 \<and> (a = b \<or> b = c \<or> a = c)} = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different isosceles triangles have integer side lengths and perimeter 23? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Because the perimeter of such a triangle is 23, and the sum of the two equal side lengths is even, the length of the base is odd. Also, the length of the base is less than the sum of the other two side lengths, so it is less than half of 23.
 Thus the $\boxed{6}$ possible triangles have side lengths 1, 11, 11; 3, 10, 10; 5, 9, 9; 7, 8, 8; 9, 7, 7 and 11, 6, 6.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a + b + c = 23"
and h1 : "a = b \<or> b = c \<or> a = c"
shows  "card {(a, b, c). a + b + c = 23 \<and> (a = b \<or> b = c \<or> a = c)} = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the number of combinations of natural numbers a, b, and c that add up to 23, given that at least two of the numbers are equal. The total number of such combinations is 6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and isosceles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b c. isosceles a b c \<longleftrightarrow> (a = b \<or> b = c)"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b c. a + b + c = 23"
shows  "card {isosceles a b c | a b c. a \<in> {1..23} \<and> b \<in> {1..23} \<and> c \<in> {1..23}} = 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different isosceles triangles have integer side lengths and perimeter 23? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Because the perimeter of such a triangle is 23, and the sum of the two equal side lengths is even, the length of the base is odd. Also, the length of the base is less than the sum of the other two side lengths, so it is less than half of 23.
 Thus the $\boxed{6}$ possible triangles have side lengths 1, 11, 11; 3, 10, 10; 5, 9, 9; 7, 8, 8; 9, 7, 7 and 11, 6, 6.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and isosceles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b c. isosceles a b c \<longleftrightarrow> (a = b \<or> b = c)"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b c. a + b + c = 23"
shows  "card {isosceles a b c | a b c. a \<in> {1..23} \<and> b \<in> {1..23} \<and> c \<in> {1..23}} = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many isosceles triangles can be formed where the sides of the triangle are positive integers, each side is at most 23 units long, and the sum of the lengths of the sides of the triangle is exactly 23 units? The final answer is 6.

a_2.formal problem:

fixes isosceles_triangle_count :: nat
assumes h0 : "isosceles_triangle_count = card { (a, b, c) :: nat * nat * nat. a + b + c = 23 \<and> (a = b \<or> a = c \<or> b = c) \<and> a \<le> b \<and> b \<le> c}"
shows  "isosceles_triangle_count = 6"

 Thus the $\boxed{6}$ possible triangles have side lengths 1, 11, 11; 3, 10, 10; 5, 9, 9; 7, 8, 8; 9, 7, 7 and 11, 6, 6.
 *)

theorem
fixes isosceles_triangle_count :: nat
assumes h0 : "isosceles_triangle_count = card { (a, b, c) :: nat * nat * nat. a + b + c = 23 \<and> (a = b \<or> a = c \<or> b = c) \<and> a \<le> b \<and> b \<le> c}"
shows  "isosceles_triangle_count = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "(int * int * int) set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a, b, c) | a b c. a \<le> b \<and> b \<le> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> (a = b \<or> b = c) \<and> a + b + c = 23}"
shows  "card triangle = 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different isosceles triangles have integer side lengths and perimeter 23? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Because the perimeter of such a triangle is 23, and the sum of the two equal side lengths is even, the length of the base is odd. Also, the length of the base is less than the sum of the other two side lengths, so it is less than half of 23.
 Thus the $\boxed{6}$ possible triangles have side lengths 1, 11, 11; 3, 10, 10; 5, 9, 9; 7, 8, 8; 9, 7, 7 and 11, 6, 6.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "(int * int * int) set"
assumes h0 : "triangle = {(a, b, c) | a b c. a \<le> b \<and> b \<le> c \<and> a + b > c \<and> (a = b \<or> b = c) \<and> a + b + c = 23}"
shows  "card triangle = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: How many triangles have integer side lengths $a$, $b$, and $c$ such that $a \leq b \leq c$, $a+b>c$, either $a=b$ or $b=c$, and the perimeter of the triangle is $23$? The final answer is 6.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and isosceles_triangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. isosceles_triangles n = card {t :: (nat * nat * nat). isosceles_triangle t \<and> triangle_perimeter t = n}"
and h1 : "isosceles_triangle = (\<lambda>(a,b,c). a = b \<or> b = c \<or> a = c)"
and h2 : "triangle_perimeter = (\<lambda>(a,b,c). a + b + c)"
shows  "isosceles_triangles 23 = 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different isosceles triangles have integer side lengths and perimeter 23? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Because the perimeter of such a triangle is 23, and the sum of the two equal side lengths is even, the length of the base is odd. Also, the length of the base is less than the sum of the other two side lengths, so it is less than half of 23.
 Thus the $\boxed{6}$ possible triangles have side lengths 1, 11, 11; 3, 10, 10; 5, 9, 9; 7, 8, 8; 9, 7, 7 and 11, 6, 6.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and isosceles_triangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. isosceles_triangles n = card {t :: (nat * nat * nat). isosceles_triangle t \<and> triangle_perimeter t = n}"
and h1 : "isosceles_triangle = (\<lambda>(a,b,c). a = b \<or> b = c \<or> a = c)"
and h2 : "triangle_perimeter = (\<lambda>(a,b,c). a + b + c)"
shows  "isosceles_triangles 23 = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: How many isosceles triangles have a perimeter of 23? The final answer is 6.
